Olivia knows that while her location will change when she goes to school, she will continue to seek out opportunities to volunteer where she can. We’re so grateful for Olivia’s dedication to our community, and we look forward to seeing what she does next!

Working closely with Northern Ocean Habitat for Humanity, where she interned, Olivia organized builds for veteran communities and other communities in need, learning and teaching skills like caulking windows to repair homes and build new ones. https://t.co/7ZbMx0vlvS

Exceeding all expectations, More students realized how much impact repairing and building homes had in their neighbors' lives. For Olivia, it was everything to know that they "were doing all they can to provide a dream of ours– a dream where everyone has a place to call home."

In her early days with Habitat, Olivia remembers being stunned by the grit and persistence of the families she met. Being able to see the difference one home makes in a family's trajectory, she knew she wanted to continue to work with Habitat for Humanity. https://t.co/4f3AIcetYw

When she first entered high school, Olivia quickly joined the Habitat for Humanity Campus Chapter. Today, Olivia is the Chapter President and has helped grow the club from 12 people to over 90 recurring volunteers.

Northern Ocean Habitat for Humanity is a nonprofit doing what it can to build a world where everyone has a comfortable and safe place to call home. They rely on volunteers like Olivia to make home ownership a reality one family at a time. https://t.co/RmqpN5lQn8

Olivia, who first began volunteering with Northern Ocean Habitat for Humanity when she was 13, was first inspired to serve when she learned about the high rate of veteran poverty and housing insecurity among Ocean County veterans.

The more homeowners she spoke with, the more Olivia understood the power of having a safe home and just how much impact she could have working with veterans like her Father, who selflessly signed up to serve our country.

Last week, our neighbor in Toms River celebrated her high school graduation. Headed to Princeton University this fall, Olivia is leaving behind an incredible legacy of service with Northern Ocean Habitat for Humanity. #ServiceSpotlight

Service is at the heart of Father Matt’s faith. It informs his work and passions.

From his experiences, he firmly believes that service is what brings neighbors closer together and can truly change the lives of people who need it most. #ServiceSpotlight

The community's response was astounding. Father Matt shared that he truly believes people want to help others and do good, sometimes they just don't know how. 

He now sees it as his duty to give his neighbors these opportunities. https://t.co/sD8KBBtwm6

He began collecting supplies and partnered with other churches, community organizations, neighbors, and nonprofits to change the lives of these families who were suddenly and traumatically in very unfamiliar surroundings.
Last summer, when our Afghan allies arrived at the Joint Base as refugees, Father Matt knew he could bring together the Bordentown community to help.

Before COVID-19, Father Matt, Christ Church, & volunteers from Bordentown came together each month to cook meals for troops living in the Joint Base dorms. 

When COVID made this no longer possible, Father Matt knew that their work could not stop, it would just have to change.

With every family helped, Father Matt’s passion, understanding, and love for our community grows. 

In partnership with his parish, Father Matt’s efforts quickly expanded and took him to @jointbasemdl.

A volunteer firefighter, Father Matt also works with thousands of NJ families experiencing homelessness, delivering homemade meals, organizing free laundry nights, and during COVID-19, teaching them how to stay safe from the virus. https://t.co/sPtosTqiZZ

Donations from 100s of our neighbors refill the Bordentown Community Panty, providing families in need with food and personal care items.

A now beloved biannual community event, "Fill Father Matt's Truck," is 1 of the ways Father Matt brings people together through service.

There are key parts of the fight against climate that require strong Govt. leadership. 
We won’t be able to accomplish what we need on emissions reduction & on rapidly scaling innovation on energy production, storage, & distribution unless all of Govt. makes investments now. 1/2
These investments will create millions of good paying jobs across the country while making sure we are handing our children a safe, clean world for them, their kids, and future generations. 2/2 -AK

I’ve focused on electrifying the transportation sector & spur innovation like offshore wind, to reduce climate change & create millions of good paying jobs. We also need to build resilience for shore communities in Ocean County so they are prepared for the next big storm. -AK

I want to see a real roadmap for how we will solve climate, not just “do something.” I’ve always believed that a transnational problem requires a transnational solution. This is the moment when we should truly commit to solving this existential threat to humanity. -AK

It’s not just about lowering emissions, but creating a strong sustainable economy around lowering emissions. We can create millions of good paying construction and manufacturing jobs. We also need to assess what communities are most vulnerable to climate, and ensure support. -AK

This is our last best chance to meaningfully tackle climate change. This requires a whole of society strategy. We should push for big steps like electrifying our transportation sector and pushing for new technologies for energy production and storage. -AK

Together, these two bills tonight are about changing systems: our system of politics and our system of criminal justice. We can only do better for everyone when the systems are built to allow us to do that. Today was an important step in that direction (end)
That means we have a system that can truly tackle the big challenges of our time. One of those challenges is racial justice. That's where the second bill, the #JusticeInPolicingAct comes in.
This bill achieves that by banning practices like chokeholds and taking other steps to change the culture of our public safety so it works for everyone.

This was a key part of what I heard when I did a series of listening sessions last year with community groups and law enforcement. There was a lot of common ground and common purpose. This bill is a step towards achieving that.

This bill is actually the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act. It's named after Mr. Floyd because he serves as a reminder of a broken system. Broken for communities of color and broken for our men and women in uniform who serve and protect.
Best practices, accountability, bringing our police and our communities closer together make for better, safer communities. That's our goal.

This bill does a lot of things, but it comes down to a few key categories: 1) it protects every American's right to vote and makes our voting systems safer, 2) it finally fights back against dark money, and 3) it strengthens our ethics laws to weed out bad actors.
Tonight we're voting on two important bills in the House. I want to take a quick minute to tell you why in this moment it was critical we bring them up for a vote (thread)

When our system doesn't work for you, it doesn't work. And when our system doesn't work, it doesn't work for you. We've seen that so many times over the past few years. This bill makes the changes we need to make the system work, and work for you.

Let's start with #HR1, the #ForThePeople Act. This is a bill that I fought for even before I came to Congress. It's a bill that strikes at the core of what so many people I talk to every day are frustrated by: a system that works for big money and influence, not every day people.
This is great news for our neighbors in Ocean County. Hope and help is on the way.
Simply unacceptable. Our men and women in uniform deserve better.
Speaking out in opposition should never be a death sentence. This is the right step forward. #FreeNavalny

Worth reading the whole thread from @GovMurphy. The 15th and 29th of this month are two big milestones in our effort to get you a vaccine.
It’s safe. It’s effective. It’s easy to transport. It’s one and done. That definitely checks all the boxes. Now let’s get some to New Jersey.
Next the bill goes to the Senate. I hope they act swiftly because time is of the essence. You deserve this help, and I’m proud to have done my small part to deliver it.
RESCUE OUR KIDS - we’re all ready for our kids to go back to school in-person, but we have to make sure our schools and teachers are ready. This bill will make sure we do it right.

RESCUE OUR MAIN STREETS - our small business aren’t just the places we work, they’re the centers of our communities. We improved the PPP and created a new fund for restaurants so our small businesses can weather the rest of the storm.

RESCUE OUR COMMUNITIES - our counties and towns have been hit hard over the last year. When they lose revenue, you lose services. Congress can help and we did because we need to protect essential workers like first responders.

This isn’t a controversial bill. The US Chamber and the AFL-CIO support it. Big business leaders and small town mayors support it. It’s a bill that provides help because that’s what we do as Americans when we’re in a crisis; we help each other.
Early this morning I promised I’d go into depth on the #AmericanRescuePlan - so here we go (THREAD) https://t.co/Swlw0IOVSl

RESCUE WORKING FAMILIES - millions of people are still out of work and millions more have been pushed to the brink of poverty. Rescue for them means $1400 direct payments and enhanced unemployment. It means help for food banks and other programs.

That means we can’t just pass money to put more shots in arms -
though this bill does that and it’s going to help you get your vaccine faster. It means we need to tackle the crisis that came from COVID. I’ll break it down:
First, let’s be clear about what this bill is: it’s a rescue plan. It’s in the name. But what are we rescuing the American people from? The totality of the #COVID pandemic.

I'll share more later today, but you can see the math here: combined, more than half of this goes to helping our working families with large percentages going toward helping small biz and state and local governments who have been stretched thin. https://t.co/hIEJn1Hu5F

The pandemic, the economic crisis, the challenge of getting our kids back to school; these problems are all interconnected, and the solutions must be comprehensive. It's why I voted to pass the #AmericanRescuePlan.
